unnormalised: Okay, so you're thinking of upping your game, huh? Whether you're aiming for a marathon like the Mumbai Marathon or just want to dominate your local badminton club like Prakash Padukone, a solid training regimen is your best friend. Forget shortcut remedies and churan – consistent effort is the real secret.

Forget shortcut remedies and churan – consistent effort is the real secret.

unnormalised: First things first: figure out your 'why'. Are you trying to shed those extra kilos picked up during Diwali celebrations? Are you dreaming of representing India at the Olympics like Neeraj Chopra? Your motivation will dictate the intensity and duration of your training. For general fitness, maybe 3-4 days a week will cut it. But if you're seriously competing, think 6 days, sometimes even twice a day!

unnormalised: Now, let's talk structure. No, I'm not talking about architectural blueprints from IIT Roorkee! Think about dividing your week. Maybe Mondays are strength training – squats, deadlifts, bench press – all that good stuff. Tuesdays could be cardio – a 10km run or some intense cycling. Wednesday? Rest, recover, maybe a gentle yoga session. Thursday mirrors Monday, Friday mirrors Tuesday, and Saturday could be a long endurance session like a 20km run or a challenging hike near Lonavala. Sunday? Absolutely mandatory rest! Remember the dialogue from "Chak De! India"? "70 minute hain tumhare paas…" Well, those 70 minutes were preceded by grueling training!

unnormalised: Nutrition is crucial, yaar! Imagine trying to run a marathon fueled by just samosas and chai. Not gonna happen. Load up on protein, carbs, and healthy fats. Think dal-roti-sabzi with a side of paneer for our vegetarians. Non-vegetarians have a wider array to choose from, but the principle remains the same: balanced nutrition to fuel your body and aid recovery. Don't forget hydration! Drink plenty of water throughout the day, especially before, during, and after workouts. Lassi after a heavy workout can be a refreshing treat, too.

unnormalised: Don't be a hero, listen to your body. If you’re feeling pain, don’t push through it. That's a recipe for injury. Adjust your intensity, take extra rest days, or consult a doctor. A pulled hamstring can sideline you for weeks, setting you back further than you think.

unnormalised: Finally, consistency is key. There will be days when you'd rather stay in bed and binge-watch something on Netflix. But remember your 'why'. Remember those goals you set. Even a short 30-minute workout is better than no workout at all. Start slow, be patient, and celebrate your progress, even the small wins. A 5km run turning into 10km? That’s definitely a reason to celebrate with a healthy (and well-deserved) treat. Train smart, eat well, and rest up. You’ll be surprised how much you can achieve with a solid training regimen!
